document_title: Modeled microgravity alters lipopolysaccharide and outer membrane vesicle production of the beneficial symbiont Vibrio fischeri
summary_full: This study investigates the impact of modeled microgravity (LSMMG) on the beneficial symbiont Vibrio fischeri, focusing on lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and outer membrane vesicle (OMV) production. Using high-aspect ratio vessels (HARVs) to simulate microgravity, researchers found that LSMMG conditions significantly increased the release of LPS by V. fischeri compared to gravity controls. This increased LPS shedding was correlated with enhanced OMV production, a process previously linked to flagellar motility. While motility-deficient mutants showed reduced LPS shedding overall, they still exhibited higher LPS levels under LSMMG, suggesting that flagellar function is not solely responsible for the microgravity-induced increase. Furthermore, V. fischeri cells grown under LSMMG demonstrated increased susceptibility to cell membrane-disrupting agents, indicating a potential alteration in outer membrane integrity. These findings suggest that microgravity can alter the physiology of symbiotic microbes, potentially impacting host-microbe interactions during spaceflight.
key_findings: Modeled microgravity (LSMMG) increases the shedding of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) by Vibrio fischeri.
Increased LPS shedding under LSMMG is associated with higher production of outer membrane vesicles (OMVs).
While flagellar motility contributes to OMV production, it is not entirely responsible for the LSMMG-induced increase in LPS shedding.
V. fischeri cells grown under LSMMG exhibit increased susceptibility to cell membrane-disrupting agents, suggesting altered membrane integrity.
OMVs produced under LSMMG conditions are larger on average than those produced under gravity conditions.
future_research_fields: Investigating the specific mechanisms by which LSMMG affects outer membrane integrity in V. fischeri.
Determining the precise composition and content of OMVs produced under LSMMG and their specific impact on host interactions.
Exploring the long-term effects of microgravity on the V. fischeri-Euprymna scolopes symbiosis.
Assessing the implications of altered LPS and OMV production for host immune responses and development in spaceflight.
Comparing the responses of other beneficial microbes to microgravity conditions.

conclusions: Modeled microgravity conditions significantly alter the physiology of the beneficial symbiont Vibrio fischeri, leading to increased LPS shedding and OMV production, and potentially compromising outer membrane integrity. These changes, observed even in motility-deficient mutants, suggest a novel response to microgravity that could impact host-microbe interactions during spaceflight.
impact_statement: This study reveals how microgravity affects beneficial bacteria, providing crucial insights into potential disruptions of host-microbe homeostasis relevant to astronaut health during space missions.
